_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Lone Pine Ag-Services, Inc maintains the anhydrous ammonia tank on the property of Lloyd A. Wulfkuhle.  Lone Pine Acres, Inc is the corporate name of the farming enterprise of Lloyd A. Wulfkuhle.  Lone Pine Acres, Inc,  whose corporate headquarters are in close proximity to the anhydrous ammonia tank, employs 5 full-time people.
1.  The Facility Policy
     The owners, owner's employees, and management of Lone Pine Ag-Services, Inc are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local Fire Department, Local Emergency Preparedness Team, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.
2.  Facility Information
     The primary activity at the anhydrous ammonia facility is the storage and filling of anhydrous ammonia tanks. 
     Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application for crop production nutrients.  
     The State Environmental Agency does a yearly  inspection of our anhydrous ammonia facility.
     The maximum quantity stored would be 84,150 lbs in our one 18,000 gal storage tank.  The maximum quantity handled would be the unloading of a truck tanker holding 48,000 lbs and the possibility of 18 nurse tanks on-site with a maximum capacity of 84,150 lbs.
3.  The Accidental Release Prevention Program
     The facility has implememnted the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1" published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc, and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia".
4.  The Five-year Accident History
     A.  There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that:
           -have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the f

acility; nor
           -to our knowledge, have resulted in off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property 
            damage, or environmental damage.
5.  The Emergency Action Plan Program
     -The facility has:
     A.  A written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29CFR 1910.38;
     B.  Provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as
          required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).
6.  Planned changes to improve safety.
     Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.

Lloyd A. Wulfkuhle
President
